news_summary: A landmark court ruling affirms that harming the climate may breach international law, inspiring renewed global commitment to protect the Earth.
news_summary_fr: Une décision de justice historique affirme que les atteintes au climat peuvent constituer une violation du droit international, suscitant un engagement mondial renouvelé en faveur de la protection de la Terre.
news_summary_es: Una sentencia judicial histórica afirma que dañar el clima puede infringir el derecho internacional, inspirando un renovado compromiso mundial para proteger la Tierra.

articles.title: Daily briefing: Damaging the climate could violate international law, court rules
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 24 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02369-1A landmark court ruling could open the door for nations most affected by climate change to sue the most polluting countries. Plus, an artificial intelligence model that can predict lost Latin text and a fish-inspired medical device that sticks to slippery surfaces.
articles.content:
A landmark court ruling could open the door for nations most affected by climate change to sue the most polluting countries. Plus, an artificial intelligence model that can predict lost Latin text and a fish-inspired medical device that sticks to slippery surfaces.

Hello Nature readers, would you like to get this Briefing in your inbox free every day? Sign up here.

Fragment of a military diploma from Sardinia. AI model Aeneas can predict text lost from a damaged inscription (grey text) without needing to know the length of the section that is missing.Credit: Yannis Assael et al./Nature

An artificial intelligence model called Aeneas can predict where ancient Latin texts come from, estimate their age and restore any missing parts. Researchers trained Aeneas on snippets of text from three of the world’s largest databases of Latin inscriptions, comprising more than 175,000 entries. The model also supports its output with a list of similar inscriptions from the data set, ranked by how relevant they are to the original inscription. When put to the test on well-known texts, Aeneas’s predictions about their age and location-of-origin were similar to that of historians.

Nature | 5 min read

Reference: Nature paper

Solid gold can take the heat

Scientists say they’ve heated solid gold to fourteen times its melting point before it melted. The team used a laser to rapidly heat a 50-nanometre-thick sample to 19,000 kelvin for trillionths of a second before it melted and exploded. Testing such ‘superheating’ of metals is relevant for subjects such as the study of molten planetary interiors. But the result of the experiment has raised eyebrows among physicists. “Do we exceed the melting temperature 10–14 times before melting? I do not think so,” says Artur Tamm, a computational physicist who reviewed the paper.

Nature | 5 min read

Reference: Nature paper

The United States is once again withdrawing from UNESCO, the United Nations science and cultural organization, ending its two-year return to the agency. Researchers say the decision is a setback for global cooperation in science and education, but came as no surprise. The country, a founding member, last withdrew from UNESCO in 2017, during the first term of President Donald Trump, cutting off more than 22% of the agency’s funds. According to UNESCO, the latest withdrawal won’t hit as hard as in 2017 because the US contribution now accounts for 8% of UNESCO’s current annual budget.

Nature | 4 min read

Features & opinion

To make energy, organisms either respire aerobically, using oxygen, or anaerobically, without oxygen. Some species can do both, but for years, researchers didn’t think any organism could do them at the same time. Now, a hardy bacterium that grows in hot springs has thrown a spanner in the works. Scientists found that the species, coined Hydrogenbacter RSW1, could use sulphur to keep its respiration ticking over if there’s no oxygen available — a process that continues even when the bacterium begins to respire aerobically.

Quanta | 8 min read

Researchers have unveiled a new medical device that can stick to soft, moving surfaces, such as the lining of the gastrointestinal tract. The team were inspired by remora, a family of fish that use a similar, sucker-like organ to hitch a ride on larger animals as they swim. The team hopes that such a device can one day be used to deliver medicine to internal organs by sticking to its inner walls, or to monitor disease symptoms such as acid reflux.

Nature | 4 min video

Reference: Nature paper

Image of the week

Stephan N. F. Spiekman et al/Nature

At first glance, you might think that the large protrusion coming from the back of this 247-million-year-old fossil — the newly-discovered Mirasaura grauvogeli — is made of feathers. But, researchers have confirmed, you’d be wrong. Instead, it’s a ‘skin appendage’ — a series of flat, stiff structures that extend vertically from the spine of the reptile. Such structures push the boundaries of what researchers thought reptile skin could achieve, as they’re neither feathers nor covered in scales. “They also must have been awkward to carry around, given that the longest is more than one-third of the length of the entire creature,” writes evolutionary biologist Richard Prum. (Nature News & Views | 6 min read, Nature paywall)
articles.reasoning: The article describes a landmark court ruling that could empower nations most affected by climate change to hold polluting countries accountable, which is a significant step toward environmental justice and climate action. Additionally, it highlights scientific and technological advances, such as an AI model predicting lost Latin text and a fish-inspired medical device, which add to the positive tone.
articles.personality_title: Court ruling opens door for climate justice
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Climate change causes serious harm around the world, especially to countries that contribute the least to pollution. So far, these nations have struggled to hold the biggest polluters accountable on the global stage.

**What happened**
A landmark court decision now says that damaging the climate can break international law. This means countries most affected by climate change could sue the biggest polluters for the harm caused. This legal breakthrough gives hope for stronger climate action and accountability.

**Impact**
This ruling empowers vulnerable nations to demand justice and pushes polluting countries to take responsibility. It marks a big step toward protecting our planet and supporting those hit hardest by climate change.

**What's next step**
Affected countries can now pursue legal cases using this ruling. Meanwhile, global discussions on climate policies may gain new momentum, encouraging countries to reduce emissions and help repair the damage.

**One-sentence takeaway**
A new court ruling makes it possible for vulnerable nations to hold polluters legally responsible, advancing the fight against climate change.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une décision de justice ouvre la voie à la justice climatique
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Le changement climatique cause de graves dégâts dans le monde, notamment dans les pays qui polluent le moins. Jusqu'à présent, ces pays avaient du mal à tenir les plus gros pollueurs responsables à l'échelle mondiale.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Une décision judiciaire historique déclare que nuire au climat peut violer le droit international. Cela signifie que les pays les plus touchés par le changement climatique peuvent désormais poursuivre en justice les plus gros pollueurs. Cette avancée juridique donne de l'espoir pour une action climatique plus forte et plus responsable.

**Impact**
Cette décision donne plus de pouvoir aux nations vulnérables pour réclamer justice et pousse les pays pollueurs à assumer leurs responsabilités. C'est un grand pas vers la protection de notre planète et le soutien aux plus touchés par le changement climatique.

**Prochaine étape**
Les pays affectés peuvent maintenant engager des actions en justice grâce à cette décision. Parallèlement, les discussions internationales sur les politiques climatiques pourraient s'accélérer, encourageant les pays à réduire leurs émissions et à réparer les dégâts.

**En résumé**
Une nouvelle décision de justice permet aux nations vulnérables de tenir légalement responsables les pollueurs, faisant avancer la lutte contre le changement climatique.
articles.personality_title_es: Una sentencia judicial abre la puerta a la justicia climática
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
El cambio climático causa daños graves en todo el mundo, especialmente en los países que menos contaminan. Hasta ahora, estos países han tenido dificultades para responsabilizar a los mayores contaminadores a nivel global.

**Qué pasó**
Una decisión judicial histórica establece que dañar el clima puede violar el derecho internacional. Esto significa que los países más afectados por el cambio climático podrían demandar a los mayores contaminadores. Este avance legal ofrece esperanza para una acción climática más fuerte y responsable.

**Impacto**
Esta sentencia da poder a las naciones vulnerables para exigir justicia y presiona a los países contaminantes a asumir responsabilidades. Marca un gran paso para proteger nuestro planeta y apoyar a los más afectados por el cambio climático.

**Próximo paso**
Los países afectados ahora pueden iniciar procesos legales basados en esta sentencia. Mientras tanto, las discusiones globales sobre políticas climáticas podrían ganar impulso, alentando a los países a reducir emisiones y reparar daños.

**Resumen en una frase**
Una nueva sentencia judicial permite a las naciones vulnerables responsabilizar legalmente a los contaminadores, avanzando la lucha contra el cambio climático.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm-colored painting of a balanced scale where one side holds a glowing, stylized Earth with swirling clouds and green continents, and the other side holds a smoky factory silhouette emitting gentle wisps of gray; beneath the scale, a calm ocean reflects the scene, and in the background, faint outlines of diverse national landmarks rise under a soft sunrise sky.

articles.title: Earth911 Inspiration: Earth Is Worth Fighting For
articles.summary:
Today’s quote is from American author Ernest Hemingway. In his novel For Whom the Bell...
The post Earth911 Inspiration: Earth Is Worth Fighting For appeared first on Earth911.
articles.content:
Today’s quote is from American author Ernest Hemingway. In his novel For Whom the Bell Tolls he wrote, “The world is a fine place and worth the fighting for and I hate very much to leave it.”

Earth911 inspirations. Print them, post them, share your desire to help people think of the planet first, every day.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights inspiration related to the environment, emphasizing that Earth is worth fighting for, which aligns with environmental progress and conservation successes. It promotes a hopeful and motivating message about protecting the planet.
articles.personality_title: Earth is worth fighting for: a message to inspire us all
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
American author Ernest Hemingway once wrote, “The world is a fine place and worth the fighting for,” reminding us of the beauty and value of our planet. This powerful quote comes from his novel *For Whom the Bell Tolls* and encourages us to care deeply about Earth.

**What happened**
Earth911 shared this inspiring quote to motivate people to think about the environment every day. They encourage printing, posting, and sharing the message to spread awareness and inspire collective action to protect our planet.

**Impact**
This simple but moving reminder helps people feel hopeful and motivated. It encourages us to see the Earth as precious and worth protecting, which can lead to more thoughtful choices and support for environmental efforts.

**What's next step**
The next step is to keep sharing this inspiring message widely. By reminding ourselves and others daily that Earth is worth fighting for, we can build stronger care for nature and inspire more people to take small actions that add up to big positive changes.

**One-sentence takeaway**
A heartfelt quote from Hemingway reminds us that Earth is precious and worth every effort to protect and preserve.
articles.personality_title_fr: La Terre vaut la peine d'être défendue : un message pour nous inspirer tous
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
L’écrivain américain Ernest Hemingway a écrit : « Le monde est un bel endroit et vaut la peine d’être défendu », nous rappelant la beauté et la valeur de notre planète. Cette citation puissante vient de son roman *Pour qui sonne le glas* et nous encourage à prendre soin de la Terre.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Earth911 a partagé cette citation inspirante pour motiver les gens à penser à l’environnement chaque jour. Ils encouragent à imprimer, afficher et partager ce message pour sensibiliser et inspirer une action collective pour protéger notre planète.

**Impact**
Ce rappel simple mais émouvant aide les gens à se sentir plus optimistes et motivés. Il nous pousse à voir la Terre comme précieuse et digne de protection, ce qui peut mener à des choix plus réfléchis et au soutien des efforts environnementaux.

**Prochaine étape**
La prochaine étape est de continuer à partager largement ce message inspirant. En nous rappelant chaque jour que la Terre vaut la peine d’être défendue, nous pouvons renforcer notre soin pour la nature et inciter plus de personnes à agir, même par de petits gestes qui font une grande différence.

**Phrase à retenir**
Une citation sincère d’Hemingway nous rappelle que la Terre est précieuse et mérite tous les efforts pour être protégée et préservée.
articles.personality_title_es: La Tierra vale la pena luchar por ella: un mensaje para inspirarnos a todos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
El autor estadounidense Ernest Hemingway escribió: “El mundo es un lugar hermoso y vale la pena luchar por él”, recordándonos la belleza y el valor de nuestro planeta. Esta poderosa frase proviene de su novela *Por quién doblan las campanas* y nos anima a cuidar la Tierra.

**Qué pasó**
Earth911 compartió esta cita inspiradora para motivar a las personas a pensar en el medio ambiente todos los días. Invitan a imprimir, publicar y compartir el mensaje para aumentar la conciencia y animar a la acción colectiva para proteger nuestro planeta.

**Impacto**
Este recordatorio simple pero conmovedor ayuda a la gente a sentirse esperanzada y motivada. Nos anima a ver la Tierra como algo precioso y digno de protección, lo que puede llevar a decisiones más conscientes y apoyo a los esfuerzos ambientales.

**Próximo paso**
El siguiente paso es seguir compartiendo este mensaje inspirador ampliamente. Al recordarnos a nosotros mismos y a otros cada día que la Tierra vale la pena luchar por ella, podemos fortalecer el cuidado de la naturaleza e inspirar a más personas a tomar pequeñas acciones que suman grandes cambios positivos.

**Frase para llevar**
Una sincera cita de Hemingway nos recuerda que la Tierra es preciosa y merece todo esfuerzo para protegerla y preservarla.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed painting of a vibrant globe gently cradled by two large, protective hands made of intertwined roots and vines, glowing softly with warm, natural earth tones, set against a calm background of layered mountains and flowing rivers that symbolize the preciousness and fragility of the world worth fighting for.
